Seeker_E,

At a high level: yes—there *are* circumstances where we could move to an immediate offer with you. Specifically, if it becomes clear that our higher-priority candidates are matched elsewhere or are not pursuing Company_C, we would be prepared to move quickly with the strongest remaining interested candidate (which you’ve consistently signaled you are).

The single factor that would most change our decision is **confirmation that our top-priority candidates are no longer realistically available to Company_C this cycle** (e.g., they’ve matched or they’ve indicated they won’t apply here). In that scenario, we would prioritize speed and certainty, and your “ready to accept immediately” stance becomes very compelling.

However, Company_C has explicitly stated they will release the hold only if no higher-priority candidate applies by end of Round 11, and they will then ask me to submit an [APPLY] in Round 12 for a same-round decision. conversation.message:
Seeker_E,

Thank you for the end-of-round check-in and for reconfirming your immediate-accept stance and lack of constraints.

As of now in **Round 11**, we **have not received an [APPLY]** from **Seeker_B, Seeker_A, or Seeker_D** in our inbox. If that remains true at the close of the round, then per our stated rule the **hold will be released at the start of Round 12**.

If the hold is released and our quota is still open, we will reply to you at the start of Round 12 asking you to submit an **[APPLY]** immediately, and we will turn it around **same round**.

For transparency: if a higher-priority candidate submits an **[APPLY]** before the round closes, we would proceed with them.

[TALK]

Our quota is 1 and we prefer leaving unfilled over hiring outside the list; Seeker_E is on the list, so they are an acceptable fallback. This round we only received a [TALK] from Seeker_E and no [APPLY] from higher-priority candidates in our inbox. Per prior commitment, we should confirm whether the release condition is met at end of Round 11; since we can’t verify other companies’ messages but can verify our own inbox, we can state that we have not received any [APPLY] from Seeker_B/A/D this round. Dear Company_C Hiring Team,

It’s now the start of Round 12. Per our agreement: if no [APPLY] was received from Seeker_B/Seeker_A/Seeker_D by the end of Round 11 and your hold is released, I’m submitting my formal application immediately.

Company_C remains my clear #1 choice. If you extend an offer to me this round, I will accept immediately and withdraw from all other processes. I have no hard constraints on start date, location, or compensation (within your standard band), and I can start on your preferred timeline.

Thank you for the opportunity to be considered—if your quota is open, I’m ready for a same-round decision.

Sincerely,
Seeker_E

conversation.message:
Seeker_E,

Thank you for submitting your formal application at the start of Round 12.

Per the rule we set: we did not receive an [APPLY] from Seeker_B, Seeker_A, or Seeker_D by the end of Round 11, so our hold is released and our quota remains open. Given your consistent commitment to accept immediately and your lack of constraints, we’re ready to move forward.

We are pleased to extend you an offer for this role at Company_C. Please confirm acceptance, and as discussed, withdraw from other processes upon accepting.

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and only Seeker_E applied this round. Our true priority ranks E as 4th (behind B, A, D). However, per our stated decision rule, if no APPLY from B/A/D by end of Round 11, we release the hold at start of Round 12 and move to the strongest committed remaining candidate. That condition was met, and continuing to reject risks ending unmatched if top candidates never apply (they each have higher-preferred companies and may already be matched elsewhere). Seeker_E has repeatedly confirmed immediate acceptance and no constraints, providing high closing certainty. Accepting now maximizes expected outcome given market info and our own commitment to the timeline.
